content: SECTION 1. FINDINGS. The Augusta Canal National Landmark in Georgia is recognized for its unspoiled areas, excellent water quality, historic landscapes, and significant mill structures. The Augusta Canal National Landmark in Georgia features excellent water quality, historic landscapes, architecturally significant mill structures, national historic districts, and undeveloped recreational areas. The Augusta Canal and related mill sites represent the development of the cotton textile industry in the South, showcasing the transformation from agrarian to industrial economy. The Augusta Canal area represents the development of the cotton textile industry in the South, leading to the transformation of the agrarian economy into an early industrial economy. Several significant sites associated with American history are located within the area. Despite efforts by various organizations, the area continues to hold historical importance. The Augusta Canal area, home to Americans of various backgrounds, is at risk of losing its cultural, historical, and natural resources without Federal Government assistance. The Secretary of the Interior has designated it a priority for protection due to its threatened status. Many local, regional, and State agencies and businesses are involved in preservation efforts. The Augusta Canal National Historic Landmark is considered threatened and a priority for protection by the Secretary of the Interior. Local, regional, and State agencies, businesses, and private citizens are eager to collaborate in preserving and enhancing its resources. The purpose of this Act is to establish a cooperative management framework for the Augusta Canal in Georgia to preserve its significant features while promoting economic development. The Act also defines the boundaries of the Augusta Canal National Heritage Area. The Augusta Canal National Heritage Area is established in Georgia and South Carolina, including lands commonly known as the Augusta Canal. The boundaries are defined in the Augusta Canal Master Plan, dated December 31, 1993. The Augusta Canal National Heritage Area boundaries are defined in the Augusta Canal Master Plan, available for public inspection in Washington, D.C. The Secretary of the Interior will publish a detailed description and map of the established boundaries in the Federal Register. The Augusta Canal Commission is established. The Augusta Canal Commission is established with members appointed by the Secretary, including five from the Augusta Canal Authority, one from the mayor of Augusta, Georgia, and one from the Georgia congressional delegation. The Augusta Canal Commission is established with members appointed by the Secretary, including representatives from the Augusta Canal Authority, the mayor of Augusta, Georgia, the Georgia congressional delegation, the Governor of Georgia, and the Governor of South Carolina. The Commission elects a chairman from its members, and vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Augusta Canal Commission is established with members appointed by the Secretary, including representatives from various entities. The Commission elects a chairman from its members, and vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. SEC. 5. MANAGEMENT PLAN. The Augusta Canal Commission is required to prepare and submit a management plan for the Heritage Area within 1 year of the Act's enactment. The plan must integrate Federal, State, and local plans, including the Augusta Canal Master Plan, to protect and enhance the area's cultural, natural, scenic, and recreational resources. The Augusta Canal Commission must coordinate plans for the protection and enhancement of the Heritage Area's resources. The Secretary can provide assistance for the management plan, which must be approved within 180 days. The Secretary must approve or disapprove the plan within 180 days. Criteria for approval include strong local support and compatibility with economic activity in the area. The Secretary must approve or disapprove the plan within 180 days based on criteria such as local support, economic compatibility, partnership potential, property rights infringement, and property rights protection. The Secretary must approve or disapprove the management plan within 180 days, considering factors like local support, economic compatibility, partnership potential, and property rights protection. If disapproved, the Augusta Canal Commission must revise and resubmit the plan with recommended changes. The Augusta Canal Commission must revise and resubmit the management plan to the Secretary for approval within 180 days. The Secretary will approve or disapprove the plan based on specified criteria. The Commission must continue to revise and resubmit the plan until it is approved. The Augusta Canal Commission must revise and resubmit the management plan to the Secretary for approval. Upon approval, the Secretary and the Commission will implement the plan through cooperative agreements with the State of Georgia and political subdivisions. The Augusta Canal Commission will implement the management plan through cooperative agreements with the State of Georgia and political subdivisions to encourage economic development in the area. SEC. 6. ENVIRONMENTAL STANDARDS. This Act does not impose stricter regulations on the Heritage Area than those already in place. No new regulations can be enforced solely due to the establishment of the Heritage Area. SEC. 7. DUTIES OF OTHER FEDERAL ENTITIES. SEC. 7. Duties of other Federal entities include consulting, cooperating, and coordinating activities with the Secretary and the Augusta Canal Commission to ensure no adverse effects on the Heritage Area. SEC. 8. Authorization of appropriations for carrying out this Act.
